Description: Neck of travertine vessel; slightly concave profile; stepped rim with flat surface and shallow engraved line below rim; entire neck formed separately, lower 5cm of neck designed for insertion into body of vessel; drilled and ground.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Turner Bequest Excavations, Enkomi
Curator's comments: See Aston 1994 for a comprehensive study of Egyptian stone vessels. Bevan assigns this to his Egyptian-Style Type Es6 ('jar with stylised 'duck's head lugs), an example of a form that is assumed to be Egyptian but sufficiently eclectic in its details to suggest a different origins. Bevan 2007, 134-43 provides an overview of Egyptian stone vessels, with a discussion of the cultural impact on Late Bronze Age Cyprus on pp. 152-153. Bibliography: Aston B. 1994, Ancient Egyptian stone vessels: Materias and forms (Heidelberg: Heidelberg Orientverlag). Bevan A. 2007, Stone vessels and values in the Bronze Age Mediterranean (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press).
Bibliographic references: Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus (P42, Fig 70)
